Award.AwardTitle: Weak and Electromagnetic Radiative Corrections in Atomic Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Quantum Electrodynamics (QED) has been a very active field in recent years. Two
theoretical techniques, S-matrix theory and effective field theory, allow the systematic
treatment of many-electron systems, with the former being most useful for highly
charged ions and the latter for neutral, few-electon atoms.
Given the success of the theory, another important direction the field is going in is the
use of the high precision of both experiment and QED theory to make atoms testing
grounds for non-QED physics. The most striking use has been parity nonconservation
(PNC) in heavy atoms, and another important use is in nuclear physics.
A first major focus of this research will be in the fine structure of helium as a way of
determining the fine structure constant. The extreme complexity of the electron g-2
approach, recently shown by an error found in Kinoshita?s calculations, indicates the
value of an alternative approach. Independent checks of a recent calculation of
Pachucki are proposed.
A second focus will involve research on highly charged ions, continuing a long standing
collaboration with K.T. Cheng of Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. Completion
of calculations of the spectra of sodiumlike ions along with extension to copperlike ions
is proposed. Hyperfine splitting in highly charged ions will also be studied.
A third research area is recoil corrections. The treatment of recoil in a highly relativistic
system has been treated only by one other group. G. Adkins and I have been working
on an independent approach to the problem, and continuation of this research is
proposed. Another use of recoil techniques is in the treatment of photon-Z boson
exchange diagrams, which have a binding singularity that has not yet been evaluated in
a Bethe-Salpeter framework.
A final goal, with broader impact, is writing a textbook on bound state quantum field
theory. Most of the techniques used in the research described above have not yet been
well described in textbook form, and doing this, along with giving a much needed update
of Bethe and Salpeter's monograph, is the intention of this work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research carried out with the support of this grant involved the application of the original relativistic quantum field theory, called quantum electrodynamics (QED), to problems in bound state atomic physics. QED, which successfully describes the interaction of the electromagnetic field with charged particles, has been extended to what is called the standard model, presently describing all of physics with the exception of gravity. The standard model is most famously being tested now by experiments at the large hadron collider (LHC) in Switzerland, but it can also be tested through precision atomic physics experiments. These experiments are much smaller in scale than the LHC, but providing the atomic theory is understood well enough, can complement the searches for new physics. One aspect of the research done involves an aspect of the weak interactions, another component of the standard model, specfically the electric dipole moment of atoms, which in turn depend on the electric dipole of the electron. Any discovery of an electric dipole moment of an elementary particle violates one of the least understood features of the weak interactions, the violation of time reversal invariance. It is known that any discovery of an atomic electric dipole moment can only be explained by new physics, and in this grant the connection between the atomic and electron electric dipole moments has been studied with QED. Further QED effects involving accounting for the finite mass of the nucleus on the spectrum of highly charged ions, where relativistic and QED effects are large, have been studied. Precision experiments on ions of uranium that have only three electrons allow tests of QED in the very large Coulomb field of the uranium nucleus, but because three electrons are present, their interactions must be carefully calculated, and a great deal of the grant was spent doing these difficult calculations. Work on a textbook on bound state quantum field theory has also been supported by the grant.
